policy_impact: The measure was amended to clarify the weight thresholds for certain penalties for fireworks offenses. [4] The offense of general fireworks or articles pyrotechnic prohibitions in the second degree was amended to include throwing, catapulting, or otherwise manually propelling ignited aerial devices, articles pyrotechnics, consumer fireworks, or display fireworks. six_year_fiscal_implications: The Act's effective date has been changed to July 1, 3000. [3] As a result, there are no fiscal implications for this measure within the six-year planning period. [4]
operating_revenue_impact: Due to the amended effective date of July 1, 3000, there will be no impact on operating revenues in the foreseeable future. [3]
capital_expenditure_impact: The appropriation to update the judiciary information management system is deferred as the Act shall take effect on July 1, 3000. [3]
fiscal_implications_after_6_years: All fiscal implications for this measure are deferred until its effective date of July 1, 3000. [3]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: The most significant change is the amended effective date of July 1, 3000, which defers all fiscal impacts of the measure to encourage further discussion. [4] Policy updates in the amended bill include clarifying the weight thresholds for certain penalties and expanding the offense of general fireworks prohibitions in the second degree to include the act of throwing or manually propelling ignited fireworks. [4] A new fine of $300 (HB1483_HD1_.HTM.txt) has been established for offenses where the weight of illegal fireworks is less than five pounds or cannot be determined. [3] Additionally, the authority of law enforcement officers to conduct inspections has been restored, addressing a concern raised by the Department of Law Enforcement. [4]
